channel.title: Smccoy's Snacks
channel.description: A short recipe book in honor of Smccoy's 21st birthday!

item.title: Sara's Summer Salad
item.description: A fresh choice for a warm summer day!Throw this together in a 10 minutes or less and you’ll be on your way.Recipe:NotesYou could totally use…
item.content:encoded:
A fresh choice for a warm summer day!

Throw this together in a 10 minutes or less and you’ll be on your way.

Recipe:

  • Add however much spinach you want to a bowl
  • Top with some quinoa (best cold)
  • Throw in some chopped strawberries
  • Chop up some almonds or really any other nut and throw them in. They're best if roasted. Just toss the nuts in a pan and heat them until golden. No need to add any oil or anything unless you want to.
  • Goat cheese! Add goat cheese crumbles. A great option is the Trader Joe's Honey Chevre.
  • Make a quick dressing. Combine balsamic vinegar, honey or maple syrup, a dash of salt, and a little olive oil in a small mason jar or something. Shake it well to combine. Pour into your salad, mix it up a little, and you're good to go.

Notes

You could totally use this as a salad template. For example, you could swap out the strawberries for peaches. Or use feta instead of goat cheese and make it more of a savory salad with more veggies.

“Car rides to Malibu. Strawerry ice cream, one spoon for two." (Rodrigo, 2021).

item.title: Blissful 'Baked' Beans
item.content:encoded: “Beans beans the magical fruit. The more you eat, the more you toot."

item.title: Benji's Breakfast Bash
item.description: 50% of Phoenix water comes from surface and groundwater from the Salt River ProjectAbout 40% comes from the Colorado River via the Central…
item.content:encoded:
• 50% of Phoenix water comes from surface and groundwater from the Salt River Project
  • About 40% comes from the Colorado River via the Central Arizona Project
  • About 10% is pumped from wells or is recycled wastewater
  • 100% of the City of Phoenix’s water supply is disinfected using chlorine
“…minerals and algae that collect in the canals that transport our surface water along to Phoenix’s water treatment plants.  The algae is removed during the treatment process, but much like a bouquet of roses that has not been in a room for hours, you still may be able to smell it” (City of Phoenix, FAQ).

FAQ: How can I improve the taste and odor of my water?

“To improve taste and odor place a slice of lemon in your water” (City of Phoenix, FAQ).
